climbs.name: Simple Man In A Complex World
climbs.fa: Sandy Fleming, Bill Currie, Bruce Hayward, Alex Tait - April 24, 1993

content.description: This is the route on the right side of the more buttress-like part of the slab.  It is another really nice route with another steep pull over the hanging boulder at the top, which is the crux.   Figuring out how to pull over this thing is surprisingly difficult and a little bold.
content.protection: 4 bolts and a light rack of gear from thin hands to fists.  Bolted anchor at the top.

climbs.name: Gutterballs
climbs.fa: Sandy Fleming, Gregg Esenwein, Carley DelPret - November 29, 1992

content.description: This is the obvious, shallow, unjammable gutter-like groove that runs up the steep lower half of the slab.  Enjoy excellent climbing up crystals and small holds and features, following The Gutter past three bolts.  From a good stance above the Gutter, place gear in the overlap and pull onto the steep upper slab to clip another bolt.  Climb the steep slab following good holds to another stance at the base of a short dihedral in a jutting, overhanging block.  Jam and stem your way up the finger crack dihedral and pull onto the lower angle slab above.  Wander up and right searching for gear to finish on the two bolt anchor.
content.protection: There are 4 bolts.  Pick a few cams and nuts from small fingers to hands and some slings.  Bolted anchor at the top.
content.location: Approaching from the Ridge Trail, it is best to rappel to the base of the climb from above using the bolted rappel anchor.  A full 60m rope is required to reach the base.

content.description: This is the beautiful slab and buttress hidden to the left of “The Eagle’s Gift” slab. If you know where it is, it is very simple to walk literally right to the top of it in just a minute or two from the Ridge Trail.
